Award.AwardTitle: Modeling Physical Processes in the Solar Wind and Local Interstellar Medium with Multi-Scale Fluid-Kinetic Simulation Suite

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to use the possibilities provided by the Blue Waters supercomputer to model fundamental and challenging space physics problems. The heliosphere is the sphere like region of space dominated by the Sun, which extends far beyond the orbit of Pluto. The Solar Wind (SW) consists of ionized atoms from the Sun. The project will model the SW flows in the inner and outer heliosphere, and compare the results with observational data. It is anticipated that the project will provide a leap forward in the simulation of complex charged and neutral gas systems. Furthermore, the proposed approach to computational resource management for complex codes utilizing multiple algorithm technologies is expected to be a major advance to current approaches. The development of resource management technologies will be essential for all future modeling efforts that incorporate a wide diversity of scales and physical processes.

The analysis of flows of partially ionized plasma that are characterized by multiple or highly localized scales and multiple processes, will have a transformative impact for heliophysics. The project will address a variety of physical phenomena occurring throughout the solar system, such as the charge exchange processes between neutral and charged particles, the birth of pick-up ions (PUIs), the origin of energetic neutral atoms (ENAs), turbulence, the interplay of the heliopause instability and magnetic reconnection at the SW and local interstellar medium (LISM) interface, plasma wave generation in the LISM, the effect of the heliosphere on the TeV cosmic ray anisotropy, and more. The project will also fit simulation results with observational data to constrain the properties of the LISM and refine time-dependent SW models. The project will incorporate the direct measurements from the New Parker Solar Probe and Solar Orbiter missions, as well as the in situ measurements of the SW from the Sun to Earth and further to the heliospheric boundary, from the New Horizons, Voyager, IBEX, and air shower observations. This project will extract the fundamental physics of plasma-neutral flows accompanied by the interaction with energetic particles. The goal of the modeling activities is to understand and interpret observations in a way previously unthinkable because of the limitations in both physical models and computing power. Components of the physical model and corresponding code routines will be made available in a publicly accessible simulation suite.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merits. This project and the corresponding time allocation on Blue Waters made it possible to perform extensive simulation of the solar wind (SW) from the lower corona to the very boundary of the heliosphere (the heliopause), where it interacts with the local interstellar medium (LISM). WE have also developed and tested different, data-driven mechanism for coronal mass ejections (CMEs). Our simulations have been thoroughly validated against observational data from IBEX, New Horizons, OMNI, Parker Solar Probe, Ulysses, and Voyagers. This allowed us to explain, interpret, and sometimes even predict observations. We have shown that the long, comet-like heliotail is essential for reproducing multi-TeV Galactic cosmic ray anisotropy data from air shower experiments. It has been shown that the "croissant" or "round heliosphere" scenarios are based on illegitimate assumptions and contradict vary many observations. We have investigated the heliospheric boundary layer of depressed plasma density on the LISM side of the heliopause and demonstrated that its origin is due to charge exchange between interstellar protons and neutral H atoms. Simulations are in a good agreement with the Plasma Wave Instrument on board Voyager 1. The effect of dissipating heliospheric current sheet and generated turbulence on the heliosheath magnetic field and plasma distributions has been investigated. We have analyzed shock waves propagating through the LISM and showed their effect on the plasma wave generation. We have investigated the kinetic evolution of the pickup ion (PUI)  distribution function in the LISM and proved its consistence with our own mechanism of the IBEX ribbon - a thin layer of enhanced energetic neutral atom (ENA) flux in the direction where the line of site is perpendicular to the magnetic field lines draped around the heliopause. We have demonstrated te importance of PUIs on the structure of the heliosphere and  ENA fluxes observed by IBEX, Cassini, and SOHO. We have performed kinetic (probabilistic test particle and full PIC) simulations of PUIs crossing the heliospheric termination shock. This made it possible to advance the derivation of Rankine-Hugoniot conditions including PUIs. We also investigated 3-D instability of the heliopause and proved its importance for the evolving width of the heliosheath. We have disseminated our results by publishing papers and making presentations at national and international conferences, seminars, and team meeting. Our results have been published in 16 papers and more than 60 presentations have been made.

Broader impact. The physics of the solar wind interaction with the local interstellar medium has striking similarities with the neutral beam heating in fusion plasma. There are also direct analogy with different bow-shock nebulae and astrotails. The PI and Co-PI of this project supervised 2 postdocs and 2 PhD students during the second year of the project. All of
them are participating in simulations on Blue Waters. In addition, Co-PI Heerikhuisen is a PI on an NSF REU project. Participating undergrads use our own computing cluster to work with data obtained on Blue Waters. PI Pogorelov used PRAC resources to participate in the NASA-supported
Community Coordinated Modeling Center meeting to identify criteria for making MS-FLUKSS available for space physics and astrophysics communities. Voyager, IBEX, New Horizons, and Solar Probe Plus missions have tremendous publicity. PI and Co-PI actively participated in all public activities related to these missions. PI Pogorelov is also Co-I on the SWEAP instrument on board Parker Solar Probe launched in August 2018. IPI Pogorelov organized the 13-th International Conference on Numerical Modeling of Space Plasma Flows (ASTRONUM-2018) in Panama City, Florida (June 2018). ASTRONUM-2019 was held in Paris, France (July 2019). The development of physical models that embrace ``coupling complexity'' via the self-consistent incorporation of multiple physical scales and multiple physical processes is viewed as a pivotal development in the different plasma physics areas for the current decade. Besides the impact on the modeling of complex plasma systems involving CMEs, our approach to computational resource management for complex codes utilizing multiple algorithm technologies is a major advance on current approaches. Our efforts provided leadership in promoting computational science and plasma physics throughout the country.  This investigation had a broad impact on education of students and/or postdoctoral researchers. This project helped us improve their understanding of plasma physics in the real nonlinear world of sophisticated plasma processes,  and expose them to modern theories and advanced space measurements.
